## 2. Internal flow

## 2. Fish Ladder

![](imgs/fish_ladder.png){width=100%}

## 2. Fish Ladder

<!-- ![](imgs/fish_ladder.png){width=70%} -->

a. Identify the key nondimensional parameter(s) that govern the flow. Explain why the *hydraulic diameter* is the relevant length scale for defining the Reynolds number in this problem.

::: {.callout-note}
The **hydraulic diameter**, $D_H$, is a metric that relates circular tubes with non-round tubes, and it is defined as:

$$
 D_H = \frac{4 \times \text{area of cross-section}}{\text{wetted perimeter of the cross-section}} = \frac{4hw}{2(h+w)}
$$
:::

## 2. Fish Ladder

![](imgs/fish_ladder_w_units.png){width=25%}

c. Calculate the maximum angle $\alpha$ such that the fish are still able to move past the dam.

::: {.callout-tip}
You will need an equation relating the pressure loss due to viscous shear forces along the pipe with the velocity of the fluid. Use the Darcyâ€“Weisbach equation: $\frac{\Delta P}{L} = \frac{f}{D_h}\,\frac{\rho U^2}{2}$
:::

::: {.callout-tip}
You will need to relate the Reynolds number with the friction factor $f$. Use a Moody diagram.
:::
